items.item_details:
The Board of Trustees offers an opportunity for the public to address the Board in four sections of the agenda: on matters of concern about Closed Session items; on matters not appearing on the agenda; on action items contained in the Consent Agenda; and prior to voting on any item contained in the Action Agenda. Each speaker is encouraged to submit a comment card to the Board clerk in order to be recognized to speak.
	Per Board Policy, three minutes may be allotted to each speaker with a maximum of 30 minutes per subject. No action or discussion shall be undertaken on any public comments except that members of the Board or its staff may briefly respond to or ask a question for clarification regarding statements made or questions posed by persons addressing the Board under this agenda item.
	For information and disability access to materials, call 408-270-6402. Meetings are held in a location accessible to the disabled.

items.item_details:
This is an opportunity for members of the public to address the Board concerning issues not listed on the agenda.
	 
The Board welcomes this opportunity to hear from the public and has established a policy for the public's participation in board meetings, which is outlined in BP 2345. This policy states that:
	 
No member of the public may speak without being recognized by the President of the Board.
Each speaker will be allowed a maximum of three minutes per topic. Thirty minutes shall be the maximum time allotment for public speakers on any one subject regardless of the number of speakers at any one Board meeting. At the discretion of a majority of the Board, these time limits may be extended.
The Board recognizes the need to encourage public participation but also recognizes the need to preserve order and the proper functioning of the meeting. Citizens addressing the Board at meetings shall therefore conduct themselves at all times in a manner appropriate to the setting.

items.item_details:
1. Evergreen Valley College Adjunct Faculty
Per the collective bargaining agreement between the AFT 6157 and San Jose/Evergreen Community College District Article 9.13 submission and recommendation:
Article 9.13 ASSIGNMENT LENGTH AND MAXIMUM LOADING - Adjunct faculty members shall be responsible and accountable for all District assigned service during the college semester for which they are employed. Assignments are limited to a maximum of 67% of a full load.
Therefore, the attached information is in compliance with Article 9.13 of the Faculty Association AFT 6157 Collective Bargaining Agreement with San Jose/Evergreen Community College District.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the faculty personnel action as submitted.

items.item_details: The District employs non-bargaining unit employees in various categories to support programs and services.  These categories are: short-term assignments with limitations as defined in the CSEA/District collective bargaining agreement; substitutes to fill positions for employees on leave of absence or in vacant positions; professional experts with specialized knowledge or expertise not generally required of, or found within, the employee classifications established by the Governing Board; and athletic support staff for athletic activities.

items.item_details:
Education Code 81655 stipulates that no contract is an enforceable obligation of the District until it has been approved by the Board of Trustees. Board Policy 6100 established the authority of certain administrators to approve contracts under the bid limit prior to formal Board approval. All contracts, purchase orders and contract revisions exceeding the current bid limit of $86,000 shall have prior Board approval as a separate board item. 
	 
This consent item presents for Board approval: all purchase orders for this period, which includes purchase orders for administratively approved contracts exceeding $1,000, as well as additional contracts, although not excuted by way of purchase order, are deemed appropriate to be added by the Purchasing Department.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees ratify the contracts, purchase orders and contract revisions for the period of November 10, 2015 through December 9, 2015 as noted in the attached documents
items.item_text: Ratification of Contracts, Purchase Orders and Contract Revisions
items.item_text_raw: 10. Ratification of Contracts, Purchase Orders and Contract Revisions

items.item_details:
Non-resident Tuition Rate:
	 
Education Code Section 76140 requires districts' governing boards to establish the non-resident tuition rate by February 1st for the succeeding year.  Education Code 76140(e) enumerates seven options, which are attached, for a district to choose in establishing the rate.
	 
The District's current non-resident tuition rate is $200 per semester unit.  In FY 2014-2015 the District recognized $1,527,157.  In order to retain and attract non-resident students, staff recommends establishing the lowest possible fee of $211 per semester unit per Option One (see attachment).
	 
Capital Outlay Fee:
	 
Education Code Section 76141 allows a district to charge a capital outlay fee to any non-resident student.  The amount of the fee shall not exceed the amount that was expended per FTES by the District in FY 2014-2015 for capital outlay, calculated at $31 per semester unit, and shall not exceed 50% of the FY 2015-2016 non-resident tuition rate, calculated at $105 per semester unit.
	 
The District's current capital outlay fee is $4 per semester unit.  In FY 2014-2015 the District recognized $30,656.  Staff is recommending maintaining the rate at $4 per semester unit.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the non-resident tuition rate of $211 per semester unit and the capital outlay fee of $4 per semester unit for Academic Year 2016-2017.
items.item_text: Non-Resident Tuition Rate and Student Capital Outlay Fee for Academic Year 2016-2017
items.item_text_raw: 11. Non-Resident Tuition Rate and Student Capital Outlay Fee for Academic Year 2016-2017

items.item_details:
Elevators and wheelchair lifts at all locations in the District are maintained and repaired by an outside service contractor, whose contract is managed by the District Maintenance Office. The service contractor is responsible to assure that all elevator hoistways, cabs, pits and machine rooms are in safe and reliable operation, and in compliance with all State regulations. There are currently 31 elevators and wheelchair lifts in the District. This quantity will increase as additional new buildings open in 2016 and beyond.
	 
District staff prepared a request for bid proposals to select a single elevator service contractor. Cost proposals were based upon unit costs for each elevator or lift. Annual escalation clauses and hourly rates for emergency services, which are typical for elevator service contracts, were also included in the bids.
	 
On July 14, 2015 the Board awarded a service contract to Schindler Elevator Corporation. At this time the District wishes to terminate the current service contract with Schindler Elevator Corporation effective January 31, 2016 in accordance with provisions of the Independent Contractor Agreement Paragraph 9 Termination under provisions of convenience with 10 days written notice. Request for termination is based upon difficulty in obtaining services over the past 6 months in accordance with contract requirements.
	 
Additionally, we request the award of service contract to ThyssenKrupp Elevator Corporation effective February 1, 2016 as the second place bidder in the process completed April 9, 2015, with the approximate cost for the first year of service of $69,552.00.
	 
The contract agreement with ThyssenKrupp Elevator Corporation will be for three years, with up to two annual renewals, for a maximum total of five (5) years.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the termination of the Schindler Elevator Corp. Independent Contractor Agreement and award a new Independent Contractor Agreement to the second place bidder ThyssenKrupp Elevator Corp. for an amount not to exceed $69,552.00 for a period of three years with two optional one-year extensions.
items.item_text: Termination of Elevator Service Contract to Schindler Elevator Corp and Award to ThyssenKrupp Elevator Corp.
items.item_text_raw: 12. Termination of Elevator Service Contract to Schindler Elevator Corp and Award to ThyssenKrupp Elevator Corp.

items.item_details:
On October 14, 2014 the Board agreed to enter into a contract with Cambridge West Partnership, LLC. for consulting services, which includes the Educational Master Plan for both colleges,  in the amount not to exceed $270,000.00. Amendment No. 1 includes additional hourly efforts and associated travel costs for additional on-site meetings, presentations and reports requested by the District related to both campuses. Cambridge West Partnership, LLC., will submit written documentation outlining the additional man hours and travel expenses in accordance with the not to exceed requirements of the original contract related to the additional work. The proposal has been reviewed to ensure the pricing reflects compliance with the original contract terms.
	 
The item in this Amendment results in an addition to the not to exceed contract of $27,000.00 and extend the contract duration.
Original Contract Amount:     $270,000.00
Previous Approved Revisions          $0.00
This Revision No. 001             $27,000.00
Total Contract and Changes $297,000.00
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Revision No. 001 in the amount not to exceed $27,000 to Cambridge West for additional hours needed to complete the Educational Master Plans for Evergreen Valley College and San Jose City College.

items.item_details:
On August 25, 2015, the Board of Trustees approved an Agreement to Rodan Builders in the amount of $960,000 to provide construction services for the Main Data Frame Relocation Project #39310 at Evergreen Valley College.
Change Order No. 001 includes Work that is the result of costs from: the addition of upgraded server cabinets for the server room, the addition of upgraded breaker capacity for the automated transfer switches, the addition of conduits and junction box for the electrical panels and the addition of a Pre-Action Control Panel for the fire sprinkler protection system.  The proposals have been reviewed to ensure the pricing reflects compliance with contract terms.
	 
Original Contract Amount                           $960,000.00
Previous Approved Changes                      $         00.00
Change Order No. 001                               $  12,486.60
Total Contract and Changes                      $972,486.60
	 
The net change to Rodan Builders’ contract as a result of all changes issued is $12,486.60 which equates to 1.30% of the original contract.  This change will be funded from project contingency established in the project budget in expectation of this type of change.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Change Order No. 001 in the amount of $12,486.60 to Rodan Builders, Inc. for the Main Data Frame Relocation Project #39310 at Evergreen Valley College.

On August 26, 2014, the Board of Trustees approved an Agreement to Blach Construction Company in the amount of $41,639,729 to provide construction services for the South Campus Development Project #32107 at Evergreen Valley College.
Change Order No. 012 includes Work that is the result of costs and credits from: deletion of door closers from Hardware Group 10 doors, addition of restroom accessories within Buildings A and B, revision of lighting fixture type at room A112 and deletion of exterior light pole at Building B, addition for the revised white boards at Dean’s Offices and deletion of Building B mirrors due to electrical conflict.  The proposals have been reviewed to ensure the pricing reflects compliance with contract terms.
	 
Original Contract Amount                               $41,639,729.00
Previous Approved Changes                         $      404,221.00
Change Order No. 012                                   $          1,931.00
Total Contract and Changes                           $42,045,881.00
	 
The net change to Blach Construction Company’s contract as a result of all changes issued is $406,152.00 which equates to 0.975% of the original contract.  This change will be funded from project contingency established in the project budget in expectation of this type of change.
	 
The Project Completion Date remains unchanged at March 10, 2016.

items.item_details:
On November 11, 2014, the Board of Trustees approved a contract to C. Overaa & Company in the amount of $11,347,704 to provide construction services for the Automotive Technology Building Project at Evergreen Valley College.   
	 
Construction contracts commonly experience unforeseen conditions or District requested design changes that require an adjustment to the contract scope, price and/or duration in the form of a Change Order.  Change Order No. 011 includes modification to hallway recessed lighting to accommodate sloped ceiling, providing power to restroom electric hand dryers, revisions to security gate hardware, added HVAC bypass valves for mechanical system maintenance, added hallway smoke detectors, relocation of lime treated and organic material on site prior to offhaul, realignment of mechanical shutoff valves per District request, additional landscape hydroseeding to reduce soil erosion, a credit for deleted slurry seal coating, additional recessed steel stud framing and drywall to accommodate elephant door frame depth, painting of the Honda colors in the Undercar and Basic skills labs as part of the Honda program requirement, and repair of asphalt along parking Lot #1 used to provide site access to Construction vehicle traffic.
	 
C. Overaa & Company submitted written pricing proposals for these changes (details in the Agenda attachment) that include the applicable increase or decrease in materials, equipment, labor, time extensions and overhead and profit.  The proposals have been reviewed to ensure the pricing reflects compliance with contract terms.
	 
Original Contract Amount                                 $ 11,347,704
Previous Approved Changes                            $   1,943,139
Change Order No. 011                                     $      126,285   
Total Contract and Changes                             $ 13,417,128
	 
The net change to C. Overaa & Company's contract as a result of all changes issued is $2,069,424, which equates to 18.24% of the original contract.  Legal counsel, Phil Jarret has reviewed this change; while the cumulative amount for change orders for this project now exceeds ten percent he has affirmed it is not applicable to this lease-leaseback contract.  This change will be funded from project contingency established in the project budget in expectation of this type of change.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Change Order No. 011 in the amount of $126,285 to C. Overaa & Company for the Automotive Technology Building Project #32111 at Evergreen Valley College.

items.item_details:
On June 9, 2015, the Board of Trustees approved a contract to R.C. Benson & Sons Inc. in the amount of $917,500.00 to provide construction services for the Ironworkers Training Center Project #31126 at San Jose City College. 
	 
Construction contracts commonly experience unforeseen conditions; District requested or design changes that require an adjustment to the contract, scope, price and/or duration in the form of a Change Order.  Change Order No. 004 is for authority having jurisdiction and increase in contractor supervision due to the extent of additional work. 
	 
R.C. Benson & Sons Inc. submitted written pricing proposals for these changes (details in the attachment) that include the applicable increase or decrease in materials, equipment, labor, time extensions and overhead and profit.  The proposals have been reviewed to ensure the pricing reflects compliance with contract terms.
	 
Original Contract Amount                              $   917,500.00
Previous Approved Changes                         $   203,480.00
Change Order No. 004                                  $     27,150.00
Total Contract and Changes                          $1,148,130.00
	 
The net change to R.C. Benson & Sons Inc. contract as a result of all changes issued is $230,630.00 which equates to 25.14% of the original contract. Unforeseen conditions account for approximately $164,400.00 of the total cost of the changes, or 17.9% against the original contract. This change will be funded from project contingency established in the project budget in expectation of this type of change and from project savings to date.
	 
Pursuant to Public Contract Code sections 20118.4 and 20659 (applicable to community college districts), a contract may be increased or decreased after the bid is awarded due to changes that might arise during the course of the contract. These changes are limited to the bid limits or to 10 percent of the original contract price whichever is greater. These limits, according to the California Attorney General, "…appear to be inserted to ensure that substantial changes are not made which would, in effect, constitute the making of a new contract."[1] Furthermore, it is in the Attorney General’s view that “… change orders are appropriately contemplated where, during the performances of the contract, unforeseen matters are discovered which require some modification to complete the contract.” 73 Ops.Cal.Atty.Gen. 417 (1990).
	 
The purpose of Sections 20118.4 and 20659 is to allow some flexibility following the award of the bid, and to ensure that substantial changes are not made which would constitute the making of a new contract. In effect, the change order provisions allow districts to negotiate changes to a contract provided the contract is not materially altered by the change order to such an extent that it would create a new project or contract which should be bid separately.  Public bidding of the increased scope of Work would not have produced an advantage to the District, and would produce a net burden and distinct disadvantages to the District. Based on the foregoing, it would be incongruous, futile, and unavailing to publicly bid the increased scope of Work.  
	 
This has undergone District legal counsel review for compliance with Public Contract Code. 
		 
[1] 73 Ops.Cal.Atty.Gen 417 (1990) footnote no. 3
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Change Order No. 004 in the amount of $27,150.00 to R.C. Benson & Sons Inc., for the Ironworkers Training Center Project #31126 at SJCC.

items.item_details:
Evergreen Valley College (EVC) is centrally located in the Silicon Valley/Bay Area, a region known globally for emergent technology and innovation for the past several decades.  The prime location gives the college high visibility and branding overseas, and the cosmopolitan community is an important consideration to potential international students.  Additionally, our recent marketing trip to several countries in Asia has increased our profile and generated interest in EVC.  Partnerships with international educational institutions and organizations could serve as a gateway for international students to commence or complete their educational goals at EVC.  
	 
International students add to the vibrancy of our diverse campus through cultural and language enrichment.  EVC has served students from the following countries: Canada, China, Columbia, El Salvador, India, Japan, Hong Kong, Mexico, Nepal, Pakistan, Poland, Philippines, Saudi Arabia, Tajikistan, United Kingdom, and Vietnam.  EVC has for the past forty years worked closely with the community at large to enhance the learning experience for our student body.  This year, we were able to organize a tour for our international students to visit key corporations in Silicon Valley, many of which are global industry technology leaders. 
	 
In November 2015, the University of Danang proposed a Memorandum of Understanding (attached to this board item) between EVC and the University for educational exchanges and activities. The proposed MOU was subsequently submitted to the Board of Trustees for approval at the December 8, 2015 meeting.  Upon approval, EVC received authorization to evaluate the feasibility of participation in the proposed exchanges and activities.
	 
As the language in the proposed MOU indicates, it is to serve as a means to facilitate and develop a mutually beneficial process for collaboration. The language stated that it is not a binding contract and does not create any legal or financial relationship between the two institutions.
 
In evaluating the proposed activities, EVC concluded that participation would entail substantial expenditures, which are resources the college does not have. Further, EVC is not approved by the State Department as a sponsor of Educator Exchanges and cannot facilitate faculty exchanges. Consequently, EVC has not accepted the proposed MOU, has not signed the MOU, and will not enter into any formal partnership with the University of Danang. 
	 
With the evaluation now complete, it is recommended that the Board of Trustees accept EVC’s conclusions and rescind the approval previously granted December 8, 2015.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees rescind approval of the Memorandum of Understanding between Evergreen Valley College and the University of Danang, Vietnam.
items.item_text: Evergreen Valley College Memorandum of Understanding with University of Danang

Pursuant to California Education Code 84040, the governing board of each community college district shall provide for an annual audit of all funds, books, and accounts of the district in accordance with regulations established by the Board of Governors.  The audit shall be made by certified public accountants licensed by the California Board of Accountancy.
	 
Administrative Procedure 6400 requires the identification of all expenditures by source of funds and shall contain a summary of audit exceptions and management recommendations, which are to be presented to the Board of Trustees.

items.item_details:
Pursuant to California Education Code 84040, the governing board of each community college district shall provide for an annual audit of all funds, books, and accounts of the district in accordance with regulations established by the Board of Governors.  The audit shall be made by certified public accountants licensed by the California Board of Accountancy.
	 
Additionally the ballot measure approved by the voters in November 2004 requires an annual financial and performance audit pursuant to Proposition 39.
	 
Administrative Procedure 6400 requires a summary of audit exceptions and management recommendations, which are to be presented to the Board of Trustees.  During the audit there were no internal control deficiencies identified; there were no instances of non-compliance or other matters identified; and the funds were expended in accordance with the ballot language and Proposition 39.

items.item_details:
On November 30, 2015 a major hot water pipe leak surfaced alongside the Sequoia Lecture Hall at Evergreen Valley College.  Hot water was flowing across the walkway creating a slip and fall hazard.  Maintenance Staff immediately closed the valves to mitigate the hazard and to stop the water leak.  As a result of this action, heat to the Sequoia Lecture Hall was shut off.  The following morning the temperature in the building plunged to 40 degrees.  With school still in session and finals approaching Evergreen Valley College was unable to redirect affected classrooms to other areas of the campus.  Accordingly the situation required quick remedial action.
	 
The District determined that the time to take a public works project to formal bid could unnecessarily expose the building to further damage and extend the disruption of classes.  In response to the emergency, the District sought the attached three informal bids and invoked California Public Contract Code Section 20654 which states, in part, "In an emergency when any repairs, alterations, work or improvements is necessary to facility of the college, or to permit the continuance of existing colleges classes, or to avoid danger to life or property, the board may by unanimous vote, with the approval of the county superintendent of schools... make a contract in writing or otherwise on behalf of the district for the performance of labor and furnishing of materials or supplies for the purpose without advertising for or inviting bids." 
	 
The District received approval from Mark Skvarna, Interim Chief Business Officer, on behalf of Jon Gundry, Santa Clara County Superintendent of Schools.  Therefore, it is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve Resolution Number 011216-2 declaring an emergency pursuant to Public Contract Code and award a contract to O.C. MacDonald in the amount of $149,569 for the emergency re-piping of the Sequoia Lecture Hall at Evergreen Valley College without the advertisement of or invitation of bids to "avoid the danger of life or property."
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees unanimously approve the resolution declaring an emergency pursuant to Public Contract Code Sections 1102 and 20654; and award a contract to O.C. MacDonald in an amount not to exceed $149,569 for the emergency re-piping of the Sequoia Lecture Hall at Evergreen Valley College without advertising for or inviting bids.
items.item_text: Resolution Number 011216-2 Declaring An Emergency Pursuant To Public Contract Code Sections 1102 And 20654; and Awarding A Contract To O.C. MacDonald In An Amount Not To Exceed $149,569 for Emergency Repairs
items.item_text_raw: 8. Resolution Number 011216-2 Declaring An Emergency Pursuant To Public Contract Code Sections 1102 And 20654; and Awarding A Contract To O.C. MacDonald In An Amount Not To Exceed $149,569 for Emergency Repairs

items.item_details:
A statewide election initiative has been approved for the November 8, 2016 General Election Ballot.  The Community College Chancellor's Office and a majority of the Community College Districts are supporting the ballot initiative with passage of Board Resolutions. The following is a brief summary of the ballot initiative:
	 
Authorizes $9 billion in general obligation bonds: $3 billion for new construction and $3 billion for modernization of K-12 public school facilities; $1 billion for charter schools and vocational education facilities; and $2 billion for California Community Colleges facilities. Bars amendment to existing authority to levy developer fees to fund school facilities, until new construction bond proceeds are spent or December 31, 2020, whichever is earlier. Bars amendment to existing State Allocation Board process for allocating school construction funding, as to these bonds. Appropriates money from the General Fund to pay off bonds.

items.item_details:
The Facilities Master Plan outlines the designs for space utilization in the learning environment to integrate meaningful teaching with enhanced student learning. As the Collegeâs educational needs change, the Educational Master Plan also changes. Consequently, both the Educational Master Plan and the supporting Facilities Master Plan are updated every five years to maintain optimal relevance and close alignment. The 2030 Educational Master plan was presented to and approved by the Board of Trustees at the meeting of December 8, 2015.
	 
The 2030 Facilities Master Plan highlights physical changes to the College that have occurred since the previous master plan, and delineates proposed additional physical changes to the College that may occur by the end of 2030 through implementation of these plans. Consultants Cambridge West and HPI Architecture, in conjunction with the 2030 Educational Master Plan, provided a series of presentations to the campus constituency groups, the College community and the general public in Fall, 2015 to allow for and encourage public inquiry. These presentations have been posted to the College's public website. All campus constituency groups, key committees and communities have been advised of the URL to access the FMP presentations. The resulting Facilities Master Plan is provided here for approval by the Board of Trustees.
	 
Once the 2030 Facilities Master Plans are approved by the Trustees, District and College staff are authorized to take specific actions necessary to implement the plans, including, but not limited to, developing project lists, allocating budget resources, executing contracts and appropriating budget (with Board of Trustees approval). The first step in this process will be for the District to begin the selection of a CEQA consultant to develop an Environmental Impact Report (EIR) for the College. The EIR will be approved by the Board of Trustees before any projects are constructed.
	 
Future revisions of these plans are expected as the College revisits its educational planning needs over the 2030 horizon.  However, the Board of Trustees must approve this facilities master plan revision and an appropriate CEQA review must take place before any deviations from the 2030 plans are implemented.
	 
The updated Facilities Master Plan has been a collaborative effort of all campus constituencies, and is purposefully end-user driven. This participative process by the campus constituents allows the best features to be proposed for consideration and adoption, and will facilitate the learning process well into the future.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees adopt the 2030 Facilites Master Plan for Evergreen Valley College.

items.item_details:
The Facilities Master Plan outlines the designs for space utilization in the learning environment to integrate meaningful teaching with enhanced student learning.  As the College's educational needs change, the Educational Master Plan also changes.  Consequently, both the Educational Master Plan and the supporting Facilities Master Plan are updated every five years to maintain optimal relevance and close alignment.  The 2030 Educational Master Plan was presented and approved by the Board of Trustees at the December 8, 2015 meeting.
	 
The 2030 Facilities Master Plan highlights physical changes to the College that have occurred since the previous master plan, and delineates proposed additional physical changes to the College that may occur by the end of 2030 through implementation of these plans.  Consultants Cambridge West and HPI Architecture, in conjunction with the 2030 Educational Master Plan, provided a series of presentations to the campus constituency groups, the College community and the general public in Fall 2015 to allow for and encourage public inquiry.  These presentations have been posted to the College's public website.  All campus constituency groups, key committees and communities have been advised of the URL to access the FMP presentations.  The resulting Facilities Master Plan is provided here for approval by the Board of Trustees.
	 
Once the 2030 Facilities Master Plans are approved by the Trustees, District and College staff are authorized to take specific actions necessary to implement the plans, including, but not limited to, developing project lists, allocating budget resources, executing contracts and appropriating budget (with Board of Trustees approval).  The first step in this process will be for the District to begin the selection of a CEQA consultant to develop an Environmental Impact Report (EIR) for the College.  The EIR will be approved by the Board of Trustees before any projects are constructed.
	 
Future revisions of these plans are expected as the College revisits its educational planning needs over the 2030 horizon.  However, the Board of Trustees must approve this Facilities Master Plan revision and an appropriate CEQA review must take place before any deviations from the 2030 plans are implemented.
	 
The updated Facilities Master Plan has been a collaborative effort of all campus constituencies, and is purposefully end-user driven.  This participative process by the campus constituents allows the best features to be proposed for consideration and adoption, and will facilitate the learning process well into the future.

items.item_details:
As part of the accountability measures for the Measure G-2004 Bond Program, the management team for the program has put into place a formal process for managing, tracking and presenting to the Board of Trustees all revisions to the Measure G-2004 individual project names, scopes and budgets.  This process adheres to the accountability standards outlined by Proposition 39 and provides transparency in the evolution of the project list.
	 
In response to input received from the Board, additional criteria was added to the Bond List Revision process at the August 25th, 2015, Board of Trustees’ meeting.  This criteria identified an added layer of information and flagging to a Bond List Revision for those projects with substantive changes (a budget change to a single project in excess of $5 million dollars, the cancellation of a project from the bond list, or the creation of a new project).  Receiving further input from the Board, the management team will now separate Bond List Revisions containing “substantive changes” onto a separate, stand alone, Bond List Revision.  In the agenda text, the team will state whether or not the item contains substantive changes.
	 
This Bond List Revision does not contain substantive changes based on the criteria set forth above.  This Bond List Revision includes a name change only.
	 
Please refer to the attached Bond List Revision Approval Request report and the Summary of Current Changes report for details on the project revision included on the G-2004 Bond List Revision dated January 12, 2016.
	 
These Bond List Revisions have been approved by the San Jose City College Vice President of Administrative Services, the Evergreen Valley College President and the Vice Chancellor of Administrative Services.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees review and approve the revisions to the Measure G - 2004 bond list, as presented.
items.item_text: Measure G-2004 Bond Program: Bond List Revision
items.item_text_raw: 14. Measure G-2004 Bond Program: Bond List Revision

items.item_details:
As part of the accountability measures for the Measure G-2010 Bond Program, the management team for the program has put into place a formal process for managing, tracking and presenting to the Board of Trustees all revisions to the Measure G-2010 individual project names, scopes and budgets.  This process adheres to the accountability standards outlined by Proposition 39 and provides transparency in the evolution of the project list.
	 
In response to input received from the Board, additional criteria were added to the Bond List Revision process at the August 25th, 2015, Board of Trustees’ meeting.  These criteria identified an added layer of information and flagging to a Bond List Revision for those projects with substantive changes (a budget change to a single project in excess of $5 million dollars, the cancellation of a project from the bond list, or the creation of a new project).  Receiving further input from the Board, the management team will now separate Bond List Revisions containing “substantive changes” onto a separate, stand alone, Bond List Revision.  In the agenda text, the team will state whether or not the item contains substantive changes.
	 
Measure G-2010 Bond List Revision No. 19 contains substantive changes with the creation of fifteen new projects.  In this bond list revision request, San Jose City College is pulling scope and budget from projects 31110 - Utility Extensions and Emergency Generator, 31116 - Campus Site Improvements, 31304 - Scheduled Maintenance and 31311 - Physical Security to create new projects  that will more clearly address individual scopes and budgets.  Additional funding for the new projects is being pulled from the surplus of budget in project 31199  - Campus Contingency.
	 
Please refer to the attached Bond List Revisions Approval Request report and the Summary of Current Changes report for details on each project revision included on the G-2010 Bond List Revision No. 19 dated January 12, 2016.
	 
These Bond List Revisions have been approved by the San Jose City College Vice President of Administrative Services, the Evergreen Valley College President and the Vice Chancellor of Administrative Services.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees review and approve the revisions to the Measure G - 2010 bond list, as presented. This revision represents substantive changes for the creation of new projects.

items.item_details:
The purpose of the Memorandum of Understanding between Silicon Valley Children's Fund (SVCF) and Evergreen Valley College is to expand the YESS Program with academic and remedial services to support foster youth on campus, a key population addressed in the College Equity Plan.  The EVC YESS Program will receive a total of $100,000 in funds to assist in supplementing program services and outcomes over a two year period (January 2016 through July 2017). 
	 
The approach will be three-pronged and will focus on developing:
1. Campus Infrastructure
2. Support Services
3. Data Collection/Analysis
	 
Student success is driven by a collaboration of campus supports.  Additional resources on campus within the YESS program will be implemented in order to connect students to various campus support services (financial aid, academic advising, etc.). The overarching goal that we are expecting to achieve is to sustain and expand the program to meet the current demand and increase the number of foster youth persisting at community college, completing an Associateâs Degree, Certificate and/or achieving transfer to university.   It is important to have comprehensive services and resources in place that foster youth need to succeed.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the Memorandum of Understanding between Silicon Valley Children's Fund and Evergreen Valley College.

items.item_details:
Based upon the Board approval of the Educational Master Plans for each campus in December of 2015 and the action item scheduled for the Tuesday, January 12, 2016 Board Meeting to approve the Facilities Master Plans, now is the time to begin a Board discussion regarding interest within the District of pursuing a November 8, 2016 Proposition 39 Bond Election.
	 
The Educational Master Plan and the associated Facilities Master Plans for the Evergreen Valley Campus and the San Jose City College Campus have identified the need within the District for additional capital project funding.  In order to execute the plans presented, the District will need to identify funding for noted projects. A Proposition 39 Bond Measure is a recommended pathway to securing the necessary funding required to institute Vision 2030 throughout the District. Due to the timeframe required in advance of the November 8, 2016 Election, the planning process to initiate a Proposition 39 Bond Election would need to be activated very soon. Now is the time for the Board to begin discussions regarding interest in pursuing this effort.
	 
Attached is an outline of action and time frame from Bond Council.
items.item_text: Discussion regarding a potential November 8, 2016 San Jose-Evergreen Community College District Proposition 39 Bond Election
items.item_text_raw: 2. Discussion regarding a potential November 8, 2016 San Jose-Evergreen Community College District Proposition 39 Bond Election

items.item_details:
The Board has scheduled regular updates to the Ends Policy Dashboard through quarterly Monitoring Reports.  At this meeting, the Board will hear a presentation about two ends policies: (1) Institutional Excellence and (2) College Experience.  With this monitoring report the Board will have an opportunity to drill into the data related to these two policies with dis-aggregated data and trends. The goal of this presentation is to 1) share where District is in relation to the dashboard targets; 2) analyze the areas of strength and opportunities for improvement within the Ends Policies of Institutional Excellence and College Experience; and 3) set direction as to the areas of focus that should be the priority of the District as it relates to specified Ends Policies.  The Ends Policy Monitoring Report can support the District in making data-informed decisions and to establish priorities for the allocation fiscal and human resources to meet the goals measured in the Board Ends Policies.
	 
The rating for Ends Policy #4: Institutional Excellence is 3.4, which is a B.  The primary indicators for this area deal with employee and student demographics as a proportion of the District's area demographics, employee and student rating of the institutional climate and satisfaction with feelings of worth and value, and employee satisfaction with district services.  Many of these items received strong scores against set targets and there are some opportunities for improvement.
	 
The rating for Ends Policy #6: College Experience is 2.5.  When it comes to student and staff satisfaction with the campus environment, safety, and engagement, the indicators receive a rating of 2.0.  When students are asked about their engagement as far as the learning environment, the indicators receive a rating of 3.0.  
	 
The Monitoring Report will go into more in-depth analysis into the trends related to these two ends policies.
items.item_text: Board Ends Policies Monitoring Report -- Institutional Excellence and College Experience
items.item_text_raw: 3. Board Ends Policies Monitoring Report -- Institutional Excellence and College Experience

items.item_details:
Per its adopted governing principles, the Board of Trustees will evaluate its performance at the end of each meeting.
	 
The Board will consider two items in discussing its evaluation:
	 
1.To ascertain the effectiveness of the meeting in attaining the advancement of the Board's Global Ends Policy.
	 
2.To ascertain the degree to which Trustees adhered to the Board adopted Governance Principle: Trustees Code of Conduct.
